awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Charlotte O. Chan is "Geometric representation theory of p-adic groups and the arithmetic of period identities." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Christopher Skinner.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI was funded by NSF grant 1802905 while she held postdoctoral positions at Princeton University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

In the last several decades, the development of the Langlands program has illuminated the deep interrelations between disparate areas of mathematics. In this grant, the PI especially investigated new interactions in this realm between representation theory (linearization of symmetries), number theory (prime number phenomena), and algebraic geometry (study of polynomials). The focus of her projects was on p-adic phenomena, both arithmetic and algebraic. Six research articles were written during the tenure of this grant and several more are in progress under collaborations formed during this period.

One of the main achievements of the PI and her collaborators in this project was the development of parahoric Deligne--Lusztig induction. From a number theoretic perspective, this can be viewed as a geometric version of automorphic induction. From a representation theoretic perspective, this joins a historical pattern of parametrizing difficult classes of representations by the much simpler data of characters of tori. Algebraic constructions of this type for p-adic groups have been studied for a couple decades and have allowed us to make important advancements in the local Langlands program. Work of the PI in the duration of this grant has shown that parahoric Deligne--Lusztig induction gives a geometric realization of these algebraically constructed L-packets.

The PI's results were disseminated through more than 50 talks, domestic and international, at conferences/workshops (20 talks), seminars (20 talks), and outreach events (10 talks to undergraduates and high school students). She additionally gave a 6-talk online lecture series through the Arizona Winter School in 2021; this was a 6-week online workshop complete with lecture notes, problem sets, and additional discussion sessions, and was aimed at late undergraduate and early graduate students from a broad range of countries.
